definition: Internet Protocol — the core protocol for transmitting data between devices in a network. It provides addressing, routing, and fragmentation.
Internet Protocol version 4 — the most common version of IP addressing, using 32-bit addresses (around 4.3 billion unique addresses).
Internet Protocol version 6 — the newer version of IP with an expanded 128-bit address space (approximately 3.4 x 10^38 unique addresses).
Domain Name System — a hierarchical system that translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses (supports both IPv4 and IPv6).
Media Access Control address — a unique identifier assigned to a network interface controller (48-bit or 64-bit in newer standards).
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol — a protocol for automatically assigning IP addresses and configuration parameters to devices in a network.
Virtual Private Network — a technology for creating a secure, encrypted connection (tunnel) over a public network such as the internet.
Security Operations Center — a facility for monitoring, detecting, and responding to information security incidents.
Security Information and Event Management — a system for collecting, correlating, and analyzing logs and security events in real time.
Indicator of Compromise — an artifact indicating possible compromise or attack (IP addresses, file hashes, domains, registry keys).
Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures — the behavioral patterns, methods, and practices used by attackers.
Incident Response — the structured process of identifying, analyzing, containing, and mitigating security incidents.
Endpoint Detection and Response — a tool for detecting, monitoring, and responding to threats on endpoints (PCs, servers, mobile devices).
The actions that are taken to protect assets by mitigating a threat or reducing risk.
Indicators of Compromise. Evidence that an attack has already occurred (e.g., malicious files, hashes, IP addresses, domains, registry changes)
Indicators of Attack. Signs of attacker intent or strategy, showing how an attack may happen (e.g., phishing email, suspicious link, exploitation of a vulnerability).
Advanced Persistent Threat — a sophisticated, long-term cyberattack campaign carried out by organized threat actors, often state-sponsored.
